description: From French réalité (“quality of being real”), from Middle French realité (“property, possession”), from Medieval Latin reālitās, from Late Latin reālis (“real”), equivalent to real +‎ -ity. Recorded since 1550 as a legal term in the sense of “fixed property” (compare real estate, realty); the sense “real existence” is attested from 1647. First attested in c. 1540.

entries.meaning: The state of being actual or real; realness.
examples: The reality of the crash scene on TV dawned upon him only when he saw the victim was no actor but his friend.
A man very often fancies that he understands a critic, when in reality he does not comprehend his meaning.

entries.meaning: A real entity, event, or other fact.
examples: The ultimate reality of life is that it ends in death.

entries.meaning: The entirety of all that is real.
An individual observer's own subjective perception of that which is real.

examples: To express our reality to the emperor.
